awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Thermodynamic Conditions in an Arc Discharge Plasma
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this study is to improve our understanding of the basic physics of arc discharge plasmas. Plasma, often called the fourth state of matter, is an ionized gas that is present in almost every aspect of everyday life; and an electric arc discharge is one of the most basic plasma phenomena that are used in industry and observed in nature. Examples of electric arcs include lightning, spark plugs for combustion, plasma  torches, arcjet facilities for supersonic and hypersonic flows, and devices for nanomaterials synthesis. Depending on the conditions of their generation and maintenance, arc discharge plasmas have a wide range of properties and parameters, many of which remain poorly understood. This study will be performed using both numerical simulations and state-of-the-art laser diagnostics to expand the understanding of arc discharges.  Training the next generation of plasma scientists and engineers will be provided through this project while awareness about plasma technologies and its importance will be raised to local K-12 students.

Despite its long history, the conditions for local thermodynamic equilibrium (LTE) in atmospheric pressure arc discharges are poorly understood due to limited experimental measurements of plasmas in thermal equilibrium. Conventional probes and optical measurements pose significant challenges since the arc core is a high temperature environment with high intensity of radiation. The focus of this project is to investigate the validity of the LTE assumption in an arc discharge operating in atmospheric pressure. Specifically, the research objectives are to: (i) develop a multidimensional nonequilibrium plasma model of a non-ablating nitrogen arc plasma coupled with a radiative heat transfer model; (ii) establish theory and analysis of the Coherent Rayleigh-Brillouin Scattering (CRBS) technique for plasma flows; and (iii) validate the computational results against experiment data, including the translational temperature obtained from CRBS and the vibrational state of nitrogen obtained from Optical Emission Spectroscopy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this NSF project was to investigate the validity of thermodynamic conditions in an atmospheric-pressure discharge plasma. Specifically, the research developed a multidimensional non-equilibrium plasma model of an non-ablating nitrogen arc plasma coupled with a radiative heat transfer model; established theory and analysis of the single-shot Coherent Rayleigh-Brillouin Scattering (CRBS) technique for plasma flows; and validated the computational results against experimental data, 

The research team conducted experimental campaigns using a novel dual-color single shot CRBS scheme, which enabled the measurement of the density and temperature of neutral species (Xenon) radially across a glow discharge. This was considered an interim step, prior to moving with using CRBS in an arc discharge, as is the original objective of the project. This step of testing within a glow discharge is important so that one can obtain experimental knowhow in interfacing dual-color CRBS with a plasma where we anticipated typical CRBS line shapes.. The experimental campaign was concluded as the principal Investigator (PI) moved to Luxembourg Institute of Science & Technology.  

Following the departure of the PI, the Co-PI at Stanford University took over the work on the project through a sub contract, since Texas A&M remained as the grant receiving university. The Stanford group developed a one-dimensional (1D) full fluid moment model that simulated the experimental glow discharge coupled with a zero-dimensional (0D) plasma global model. The experimental data obtained by single-shot CRBS were used for validation of the multi-scale fluid model. The Stanford team developed an in-house direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) code both in 1D and two dimensions (2D) to test the particle-light interaction due to single-shot CRBS. The optical lattice generated by two pump laser beams was taken into account within the code. The optical lattice was characterized by the light amplitude (intensity) as well as the frequency and wavelength. Assuming that the wavelength of the optical lattice is not modified (chirped), a typical simulation employs a sufficient number of macroparticles to resolve the velocity distribution functions, e.g., 100 million macroparticles in a 1D CRBS system. The code was parallelized using message passing interface. The computational results obtained from the 1D DSMC code showed great agreement with published results [X. Pan, M. N. Shneider, and R. B. Miles, “Coherent Rayleigh–Brillouin scattering in molecular gases,” Phys. Rev. A 69 , 033814 (2004)]. The analysis of frequency chirped CRBS was undertaken with  the DSMC code and concluded that the nonlinear particle trapping within a chirped optical lattice does not allow the coherent particle trapping, resulting in small-amplitude density modulations. This is proposed as a limitation of the CRBS (i.e., the chirp rate vs. the mass of the gas), which advanced our understanding of single-shot CRBS.

 

Publications

 J. Bak, R. Randolph, and A. Gerakis, ”Dual color, frequency, pulse duration and shape agile laser system for particle spectroscopy and manipulation”, Opt. Express 30, 41709--41723 (2022)

J. Bak, R. Randolph, and A. Gerakis, "Torr-level, seedless, non-resonant velocity distribution function measurement with a dual-color, single-shot coherent Rayleigh–Brillouin scattering scheme", J. Phys. D: Appl. Phys. 56 074001 (2023)

 

Presentations 

S. Suzuki, A. Gerakis, and K. Hara, “Direct simulation Monte Carlo of single-shot coherent Rayleigh- Brillouin scattering”, 76th Annual Gaseous Electronics Conference, Ann Arbor, MI, October 2023 (poster)

R. Randolf, S. Suzuki, K. Hara, and A. Gerakis, “Single shot, non-resonant, four-wave mixing laser diagnostics for low temperature plasmas”, 76th Annual Gaseous Electronics Conference, Ann Arbor, MI, October 2023 

R. Randolf, S. Suzuki, K. Hara, and A. Gerakis, “Single shot, non-resonant, four-wave mixing laser diagnostics of heavy species in low temperature plasmas", XXXV ICPIG, Egmond aan Zee, Netherlands, July 2023 [invited talk]

S. Suzuki, A. Gerakis, and K. Hara, “Direct Simulation Monte Carlo of single-shot coherent Rayleigh Brillouin scattering”, XXXV ICPIG, Egmond aan Zee, Netherlands, July 2023 (poster)

S. Suzuki, A. Gerakis, and K. Hara, “Computational modeling of coherent Rayleigh-Brillouin scattering (CRBS) for partially ionized plasmas”, 50th IEEE ICOPS, Santa Fe, NM, May 2023

S. Suzuki, R. Randolph, A. Gerakis, and K. Hara, "Fluid modeling and coherent Rayleigh-Brillouin scattering measurements of gas temperature in a xenon DC glow discharge plasma", IF2.00008, 75th Annual Gaseous Electronics Conference, Sendai, Japan, Oct 2022
